content:
The Local Government Association (LGA) has flagged Pendle Borough Council's planning service as the most expensive of any district council in the North West of England. In a borough where the external auditor has already identified significant financial weaknesses, a disproportionately costly planning department raises urgent questions about efficiency, staffing, and value for money.

What the LGA Found

The LGA's analysis of planning service costs across district councils identified Pendle as an outlier. The cost of running Pendle's planning service — relative to the number of planning applications processed — is higher than any comparable district council in the North West region.

This matters for a simple reason: planning application fees (set nationally by government) should partially offset the cost of running the service. When costs are disproportionately high, the planning service becomes a significant net drain on the council's general fund — money that could otherwise be spent on other services.

The Numbers

Council Est. Planning Spend Est. Applications/Year Est. Cost Per Application Est. Fee Income Est. Net Cost to Council
Pendle ~£1.8M ~550-600 ~£3,000-£3,270 ~£600K ~£1.2M
Burnley ~£1.2M ~600-650 ~£1,850-£2,000 ~£650K ~£550K
Hyndburn ~£1.0M ~450-500 ~£2,000-£2,220 ~£450K ~£550K
NW District Average Varies Varies ~£1,800-£2,200 Varies Varies

Figures are estimates based on published budget data, planning statistics, and LGA benchmarking data. Actual figures may vary depending on categorisation and accounting methods.

At an estimated cost per application of £3,000-£3,270, Pendle's planning service is approximately 50-80% more expensive per application than the North West district average, and significantly more costly than either Burnley or Hyndburn.

Why Might Pendle Be More Expensive?

There are several possible explanations for higher planning costs, though none fully explains why Pendle would be the most expensive in the entire region:

Possible Factor Explanation Does This Explain the Gap?
Listed buildings and conservation Pendle has significant heritage assets requiring specialist assessment Partially — other heritage-rich areas manage costs better
Consultant reliance Using external planning consultants for specialist work at premium rates Possibly significant — consultant costs are typically 2-3x in-house staff costs
Staffing levels More planning officers per application than comparable councils Possibly significant — needs investigation
Enforcement costs High volumes of planning enforcement work (investigating breaches) Partially — enforcement is necessary but costs should be proportionate
Complex applications Higher proportion of major or complex applications requiring more officer time Unlikely — Pendle does not have significantly more major applications than comparable councils
Support service recharges Overhead costs (IT, HR, accommodation) allocated disproportionately to planning Possibly — accounting methods can inflate apparent departmental costs

Why This Matters

For a council with a net revenue budget of only £12-13 million, the difference between a planning service costing £1.2 million and one costing £1.8 million is £600,000 per year. That is not a trivial sum — it is equivalent to roughly 5% of the council's entire spending power.

In a context where reserves are being depleted to cover a cumulative budget gap of £8.26 million, finding £600,000 in planning efficiency savings would make a meaningful contribution to closing that gap.

More broadly, an expensive planning service has knock-on effects. If applicants and developers perceive that Pendle is slow or costly compared to neighbouring authorities, they may choose to invest elsewhere — undermining the economic regeneration that the borough badly needs.

CIPFA Benchmarking

The Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy (CIPFA) publishes benchmarking data that allows councils to compare their costs on a like-for-like basis. The key metrics include:

  • Cost per planning application — Pendle's figure is estimated to be 50-80% above the peer group average
  • Cost per head of population — How much each resident effectively pays for the planning service
  • Income as a percentage of expenditure — What proportion of costs are recovered through fees — a lower percentage indicates a larger net burden on taxpayers
  • Speed of decision-making — Whether the higher cost translates into faster decisions (if it does not, what is the additional spending achieving?)

Questions the Council Must Answer

  • What is the planning department's total cost? — Including staffing, consultants, overheads, enforcement, appeals, and all support service recharges — what is the full cost of the planning function?
  • How many FTE staff are employed? — What is the total full-time equivalent headcount in the planning department, and how does this compare to CIPFA nearest neighbours?
  • What proportion of spending is on external consultants? — Are specialist functions being outsourced at premium rates when in-house provision might be more cost-effective?
  • How does the cost per application compare to CIPFA benchmarks? — Has the council formally benchmarked its planning costs against statistical neighbours? If so, what did the comparison show?
  • Has a service review been conducted? — Given the LGA's findings, has the council commissioned or undertaken a review of its planning service costs and efficiency?
  • What is the income recovery rate? — What percentage of planning costs are recovered through application fees and other income? How does this compare to the national average?

A Question of Priorities

Every pound spent on an inefficient planning service is a pound that cannot be spent on other priorities — homelessness prevention, environmental services, community safety, or maintaining the reserves that stand between the council and financial failure. Pendle cannot afford the luxury of being the most expensive planning authority in the North West.

Cost estimates in this article are based on published council budget documents, LGA peer review findings, CIPFA benchmarking data, and published planning application statistics. Actual figures may differ depending on accounting methodology and cost categorisation. This article does not allege inefficiency — it identifies questions that the data raises.
